author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: $1B boost to support NYC afforable housing: officials
text:
Aaron Showalter/for New York Daily News The AFL-CIO unveiled a new strategy to invest the huge sum as Mayor de Blasio vows to preserve and create 200,000 affordable apartments by 2025. A cool $1 billion in union and city worker pension funds will help support the push for affordable housing in the city, officials announced Thursday.
The AFL-CIO unveiled a new strategy to invest the huge sum as Mayor de Blasio vows to preserve and create 200,000 affordable apartments by 2025.
Some of that will target crumbling NYCHA developments in need of repair, and finance new 100% affordable housing on authority land.
DE BLASIO HOLDS FIRST TOWNHALL MEETING OF MAYORALTY IN MANHATTAN, TALKS RENT AND AFFORDABLE HOUSING
The Housing Authority is currently planning on putting up hundreds of such apartments on three developments, plus hundreds more at half the market rate.
The union plan includes partnering with the United Clergy Task Force to provide $400 million for up to 7,500 new low — and moderate income apartments citywide.
To help out, Controller Scott Stringer Thursday committed $150 million of city worker pension funds toward the project.
“"We welcome the support of working people and all officials to keep New York City affordable,” said mayoral spokesman Wiley Norvell.
